    How to use this package

    Mauricio Vargas

    2020-01-09

    basic-usage.Rmd

    International Trade Example

    This example is inspired after the visualizations from Hausmann et al. (2014).

    Package data

    I’ll use this demo dataset to illustrate the essential usage of the functions within this package.

    library(binet)

trade
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
## # Groups:   reporter_iso [158]
##    country product export_value
##    <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
##  1 afg     0106             621
##  2 afg     0405            3380
##  3 afg     0407           60807
##  4 afg     0501         1466840
##  5 afg     0504         1466840
##  6 afg     0703           85258
##  7 afg     0712            9057
##  8 afg     0714          164694
##  9 afg     0801         8482381
## 10 afg     0802         8437060
## # … with 44,425 more rows

    Balassa Index

    You can obtain Balassa Index with balassa_index().

    bi <- balassa_index(
  data = trade,
  source = "country",
  target = "product",
  value = "export_value"
)

bi
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
##    source target value
##    <chr>  <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 afg    0106       0
##  2 afg    0405       0
##  3 afg    0407       0
##  4 afg    0501       1
##  5 afg    0504       1
##  6 afg    0703       0
##  7 afg    0712       0
##  8 afg    0714       1
##  9 afg    0801       1
## 10 afg    0802       1
## # … with 44,425 more rows

    Another possibility is to obtain Balassa Index without discretization.

    bi_dec <- balassa_index(
  data =trade,
  source = "country",
  target = "product",
  value = "export_value",
  discrete = F
)

bi_dec
    ## # A tibble: 44,435 x 3
##    source target    value
##    <chr>  <chr>     <dbl>
##  1 afg    0106    0.0412 
##  2 afg    0405    0.00944
##  3 afg    0407    0.275  
##  4 afg    0501   14.4    
##  5 afg    0504   20.7    
##  6 afg    0703    0.271  
##  7 afg    0712    0.220  
##  8 afg    0714    3.18   
##  9 afg    0801   34.4    
## 10 afg    0802   48.0    
## # … with 44,425 more rows

    Complexity Measures

    You can compute complexity indexes (e.g. such as the Economic Complexity Index and Product Complexity Index) by using complexity_measures(). The calculations methods are fitness (default), reflections, eigenvalues. See (Mariani et al. 2015) for the methodological details.

    com_fit <- complexity_measures(balassa_index = bi)

com_fit$complexity_index_source
    ## # A tibble: 158 x 2
##    source value
##    <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 deu    28.8 
##  2 fra    21.4 
##  3 usa    14.1 
##  4 nld    11.5 
##  5 che    10.5 
##  6 gbr     9.81
##  7 ita     9.61
##  8 swe     7.35
##  9 aut     7.34
## 10 jpn     7.27
## # … with 148 more rows
    com_fit$complexity_index_target
    ## # A tibble: 991 x 2
##    target value
##    <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 7111    75.1
##  2 2850    55.9
##  3 8804    32.1
##  4 9307    24.7
##  5 9112    20.2
##  6 3505    19.6
##  7 3813    14.3
##  8 7507    12.6
##  9 2927    12.1
## 10 2810    11.8
## # … with 981 more rows
    com_ref <- complexity_measures(
  balassa_index = bi,
  method = "reflections"
)

com_ref$complexity_index_source
    ## # A tibble: 158 x 2
##    source value
##    <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 deu     2.23
##  2 spm     2.20
##  3 fro     2.04
##  4 che     2.03
##  5 swe     1.99
##  6 jpn     1.91
##  7 aut     1.86
##  8 fra     1.86
##  9 ddr     1.84
## 10 gbr     1.83
## # … with 148 more rows
    com_ref$complexity_index_target
    ## # A tibble: 991 x 2
##    target value
##    <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 7111    1.73
##  2 9112    1.57
##  3 8804    1.43
##  4 8208    1.40
##  5 9108    1.37
##  6 7107    1.34
##  7 4906    1.33
##  8 8468    1.32
##  9 3813    1.32
## 10 7221    1.31
## # … with 981 more rows
    com_eig <- complexity_measures(
  balassa_index = bi,
  method = "eigenvalues"
)

    Proximity

    Proximity matrices are used to create projections e.g. (country-country and product-product networks) for bipartite networks. Using proximity() is straightforward.

    pro <- proximity(
  balassa_index = bi,
  balassa_sum_source = com_fit$balassa_sum_source,
  balassa_sum_target = com_fit$balassa_sum_target
)

pro$proximity_source
    ## # A tibble: 10,432 x 3
##    source target   value
##    <chr>  <chr>    <dbl>
##  1 ago    afg    0.0962 
##  2 alb    afg    0.219  
##  3 arg    afg    0.120  
##  4 aus    afg    0.111  
##  5 aut    afg    0.00690
##  6 bdi    afg    0.0714 
##  7 bel    afg    0.00938
##  8 ben    afg    0.107  
##  9 bfa    afg    0.0816 
## 10 bgr    afg    0.0945 
## # … with 10,422 more rows
    pro$proximity_target
    ## # A tibble: 417,822 x 3
##    source target value
##    <chr>  <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 0102   0101   0.346
##  2 0103   0101   0.263
##  3 0104   0101   0.421
##  4 0106   0101   0.2  
##  5 0201   0101   0.381
##  6 0203   0101   0.474
##  7 0204   0101   0.158
##  8 0205   0101   0.368
##  9 0206   0101   0.316
## 10 0207   0101   0.368
## # … with 417,812 more rows

    Networks

    The projections() function is designed to use igraph for the internal computations and also to pass proximity-based networks to igraph, ggraph or export to Cytoscape by saving the output as csv/tsv.

    net <- projections(
  proximity_source = pro$proximity_source,
  proximity_target = pro$proximity_target,
  tolerance = 0.05
)

net$network_source
    ## # A tibble: 272 x 3
##    source target value
##    <chr>  <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 irn    syr    0.344
##  2 irn    alb    0.375
##  3 irn    tur    0.348
##  4 irn    afg    0.5  
##  5 npl    afg    0.214
##  6 syr    afg    0.357
##  7 ago    ben    0.339
##  8 ago    khm    0.308
##  9 ago    moz    0.304
## 10 ago    per    0.358
## # … with 262 more rows
    net$network_target
    ## # A tibble: 1,800 x 3
##    source target value
##    <chr>  <chr>  <dbl>
##  1 9614   4202   0.529
##  2 9614   0101   0.579
##  3 0102   0201   0.5  
##  4 0102   0104   0.423
##  5 0103   0505   0.647
##  6 1102   1005   0.5  
##  7 1102   0105   0.417
##  8 4803   4707   0.615
##  9 4803   0105   0.417
## 10 0106   1302   0.514
## # … with 1,790 more rows

    Just two basic examples with ggraph.

    library(igraph)
library(ggraph)
library(magrittr)

set.seed(1813)

net$network_source %>%
  graph_from_data_frame(directed = F) %>%
  ggraph(layout = "kk") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = value, edge_width = value),
                 edge_colour = "#a8a8a8") +
  geom_node_point(color = "darkslategray4", size = 8) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), vjust = 2.2) +
  ggtitle("Country Projection") +
  theme_void()

    net$network_target %>%
  graph_from_data_frame(directed = F) %>%
  ggraph(layout = "fr") +
  geom_edge_link(aes(edge_alpha = value, edge_width = value),
                 edge_colour = "#a8a8a8") +
  geom_node_point(color = "darkslategray4", size = 4) +
  geom_node_text(aes(label = name), vjust = 2.2) +
  ggtitle("Product Projection") +
  theme_void()

    References

    Hausmann, Ricardo, César Hidalgo, Sebastián Bustos, Michele Coscia, Alexander Simoes, and Muhammed Yildirim. 2014. The Atlas of Economic Complexity: Mapping Paths to Prosperity. MIT Press. https://doi.org/10.7551/mitpress/9647.001.0001.

    Mariani, Manuel, Alexandre Vidmer, Matsúš Medo, and Yi-Cheng Zhang. 2015. “Measuring Economic Complexity of Countries and Products: Which Metric to Use?” The European Physical Journal B 88 (11): 293. https://doi.org/10.1140/epjb/e2015-60298-7.
